reviewText:
This key was obtained for the purposes of review

Summary:
A hard one to just bring a recommended/not recommended verdict. The cute aesthetic actually hides a game that can be pretty difficult at times, which causes a mish mash very early on. It's a mixture of tower defense and strategy that plays a bit differently...and it's going to be very hit and miss for players out there. On one hand, the different turrets and the uses of citizens as helpers gives the game a bit of strategy, and can be really key in overcoming the difficult elements pushed forward. On the other hand, there's trial and error elements that occur with tower placement being so critical, and not being able to see where exactly the path the enemy is going becomes rather hard to stomach at times. This Xbox and PC title offers something different, but in a genre where you expect a bit of the same, it could be really hard to swallow. The 20$ price tag will be the deciding factor for a lot of people: there's content here, but it may be a title to wait for a sale on. Don't get me wrong, it's worth a look, but for some, it'll be something you'll need to wait for. It has a lot of strengths, but it's that one major weakness that stands out for me. If that was fixed, I could see an easy recommendation for a lot of players.

Gameplay Footage and Video Review:  https://youtu.be/kdkuW_56GIw

Lists:

+:
The cute aesthetic stands out, as the fun bouncing enemies are just fun to look at, but actually make a contrast rather well with the destruction they cause. The game oozes charm, even down to the descriptions of survivors.
Citizens/Survivors as a resource in the game is actual a cool mechanic. Deciding whether to use them to power up your turrets, where they can be put into harms way, is great. And little touches like being able to build buildings faster with them adds another level of depth for advanced players. It would have been easy to make this an escort quest of sorts, but Mechabit goes one step beyond.
Simple, but has depth. A good intro into a strategy game series for those who are looking for something.
Reasons to use selection of turrets. Each turret has a strength with its range and abilities against the variety of enemies you will face.
The game controller support shows why it was designed for the Xbox One. And yet, it doesn't necessarily hurt the keyboard controls either. It's very rare to see a strategy game have a good implementation on a controller, and yet Kaiju Panic found a way to implement it.
Game stands out with the resource gathering being tied to actually physically picking them up, meaning it's a choice to go grab the resources you may need during battle. At first, found it annoying, but understood why they did it over time.
Upgrades are meaningful, and are necessary. Gives you reasons to do things over and over again.
Hotkey implementation makes buildings, once you remember their bindings, rather easy to put down without the use of the secondary menus.
Not a bad soundtrack.
-:
Trial and Error gameplay. Turret placement is so critically important due to it being able to be destroyed, and with no way to see the exact path the enemies will come, that will lead to frustration. Losing a turret early on can be a death sentence at times, especially on boss levels.
Will appeal to younger and more casual gamers....which is a problem because the game can be rather difficult. Part of that is design choices on the T+E gameplay as mentioned in the first negative, but even I was getting frustrated at times with it.
Would like to have seen an element of upgrading turrets in match, which would have added to the complexity.
The placement of survivors in turrets can be annoying. While yes, there are some presets for putting people into turrets based on status/balanced/power, this is where the game shows its Xbox One cross-platform nature, as having to cycle through individual citizens can be annoying. Feel like UI could have been made a little more easy to see there.
The price of the game may be a problem for some. There seems to be 30 levels, and for 20 bucks that may work for some, but the frustration of having to replay levels will be a major issue for some.
Would like to have seen a classic UI bar from strategy games to show the key bindings for turrets, to help in game execution.
Game is slow to start up at times before the Kaiju show up. While this is time to allow to get critically setup, it can really hurt the pace of the game.

reviewText:
Meet the field commander, Having a normal day, mid-way through a normal week, thinking about normal things, while collecting normal purple crystals from around a normal crater formed by a normal purple crystal meteor...And then giant plushie monsters appear and the field commander stands those still within their homes on the wrong side of a river...oh boy.
We make amends, We rescue survivors and force them to build military turret defences and then force them to work/deploy said turret defenses... So much for normal coffee.

Review - Another bright and happiness inducing game from Mechabit, a small indie studio. Giant plushie styled monsters try to attack your castle/fort/thingy but, not civilians, therefore you claim the civilians as work animals that they are. Build this, Shoot that, your towers destoryed run around in panic until you calm down and we'll retry the mission.

Monster come colour coded and have indicators to what comes from where so as long as you're equipt with awesomeness your all good. Sadly there is a bit of grindiness with getting awesomeness as the game does rely on earning research points, earnt from monster deaths (small amount) which are then used to unlock new turrets and upgrades (large price).

Though overall its a decent iso style game to relax with for that long term minimal effort gaming goodness thats required with busy lifestyles.

Youtube - https://youtu.be/Apugz5ZxKqs

Mechabit - http://www.mechabit.co.uk/blog/kaijupanic/

Steam - http://store.steampowered.com/app/352760/

reviewText:
Here you play as a commander and must muster civillians to construct  and  man defenses
against kaiju, of which there are various types, with vulnerabilities against certain defences and resistances against others.

Investing Science  earned  from defeated enemies and clearing maps  you can upgrade your commander for faster construction time, movement speed etc and upgrade your defences unlocking additional properties such as pushback increased range etc

Killing kaiju by balancing what you build where you place it and what civillians you have manning what, for example if you leave civillians in defences across the map to improve them, they cant help you build  defenses for an incoming wave or repair structures that may have been damaged, or you may have difficulty evacuating them if required

Early game severes as an extended tutorial introducing how different types of kaiju and weapons interact but more types are intrroduces as you progress through levels and to 100% all missions will require going back once you have more upgrades adding a level of replayability due to bonus objectives, and also allowing you to test new weapon unlocks etc

Very fun,  a well excecuted example of the genre .

reviewText:
So, this game looks super cute and fluffy, you're a little general leading your little Duplo citizens in fending off cuddly alien monsters.  The theme pays homage to Japanese monster films of Godzilla fame (there's even a Chibizilla end-stage boss), whilst the gameplay is an innovative take on the tower defence genre by mashing it up with some RTS action.

Be warned though, If you let the cutesy character design and bright lollypop colours lull you into a false sense of security, then you're going to get your cream buns handed to you on a plate.

Whilst its family friendly graphics may make it look like something that's aimed at children or at the casual" market
date: it's most certainly geared towards people who have cut their gaming teeth on various tower defence games.  After two cursory simple levels to get you accustomed to the controls
recommended: it throws you in at the deep end once the kaiju appear. It's a little like paddling about in the shallows one minute and then finding yourself in dangerous Kaiju-infested waters the next.  I was definitely caught off-guard when I expected the entirety of stage 1 to be a breeze
voteText: I found myself barely passing level 1.2 by the skin of my teeth!  (WTF? Level 1.2? I guess it turns out that I'm crappy at tower defence games after all?)\n\nThat's a pretty steep difficulty curve
helpfulPercent: I can only presume that they've decided it to ratchet it up right from the beginning as a way to offset that cutesy image.  It ensures that your first impression is that at its core
votesTotal: it just happens to be wrapped in a sweet candy shell.  Ultimately
votesFunny: I'm glad that it does so

As such

column31: so I love a good story.  But let's be honest

reviewText:
While at its' heart Kaiju Panic is a tower defense game, the game actually does some new things that distinguishes itself from other tower defense games.

To gather resources Kaiju Panic borrows from the RTS genre where you need to build extractors that gather resources from deposits on the map. In each level you can also rescue civilians which you can use to man your turrets (increasing their power) or use them to build towers faster or repair damaged towers. The tower defense mechanics in the game are also pretty good. These two mechanics make Kaiju Panic stand out among a lot of the other tower defenses out there.
When talking about Kaiju Panic you need to bring up the art style which is fantastic. The graphics are cutesy but are really well done.

The art style hides the fact that Kaiju Panic is not an easy tower defense. I would say that it is a medium to hard tower defense. The game requires a lot of trial and error and at times you might have to grind to get enough research points to purchase new upgrades.

While Kaiju Panic might not be for everyone, I liked it. I thought it was a good tower defense. If you don't like tower defenses I don't think it will change your mind. Due to the price of $20 I can't really recommend it to people who only casually enjoy tower defenses. I would recommend that these people wait for a sale on the game. If you really like the theme and tower defenses though I think you will like Kaiju Defense.

Note: I received a free review copy of the game.

Read My Full Review[www.geekyhobbies.com]

reviewText:
If you enjoy tower defense games such as defense grid or Revenge of the Titans you'll love this game.

There's plenty of content in the form of researching weapons and skills and for those of you who want to perfect every single level.

The Graphics are simple but that's not a bad thing.  The monster designs are very cute and reminiscent of its namesake the Japanese Kaiju movies.

I'd like to have a bit more customisation in terms of resolutions, windowed mode, and changing keyboard shortcuts.

But apart from that a very enjoyable game.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This game is up there with Pixeljunk Monsters now that it has coop.

This is a very challenging little game!  The game really challenges you to get your level set up right to combat the waves of incoming monsters using the finite resources to hand.  Though it does suffer from a level of grinding to unlock the more powerful weapons and the like, it's never a chore.  Though not turn based, the cutesy graphics and the challenging gameplay remind me a lot of Advance Wars and the thrill you got from beating a level.\n\nIt's a game I'd recommend to people who like to work for their victories!
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I Like this game, most levels take multiple play throughs to get 3/3 objectives (Stars, in most other games), and although I can understand grinding may make it easier I have not had to do any grinding for upgrades yet (2 of 6 worlds complete). The biggest advantage in the second play through is knowing the enemy types and directions, as there are four tower types in this game and each is very effective at countering certain types of enemies. Using the right tower types in the right zones is key to winning, unlocking all of the upgrades is not required.

The actual gameplay is a lot like revenge of the titans, where you have harvestors and turrets and have to defend with the limited resources that your harvestors provide, except you actually have to collect said resources and build the towers within your characters range. You are also encouraged to be close to the enemies to pickup science upgrade points for your permanent upgrades to towers / character. I find that this keeps me busy for every map on the first play through and only on repeat playthroughs (If I missed objectives) do I find myself with enough time to wait for the waves to spawn.

The game provides a fun amount of challenge and gives you the tools to overcome it.

reviewText:
FULL DISCLOSURE: I was given a press copy of this game prior to release. It is your right to disregard my opinion based on this fact, but I assure you that this has never affected, and WILL never affect, the way in which I construct this or any other review I write.

If you’d prefer a video version of this review have a look here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Lh8kx23DDRI

Kaiju Panic, a new Tower Defence kind-of-action hybrid developed by Mechabit Limted. This is their first game on Steam, they’ve released a couple of smaller games and one or two VR games but for all intents and purposes I consider this their first major release.

As I said, it’s a tower defence game, but it has some atypical elements to it. I called it kind-of-action, but that’s not even really accurate. You basically play this game from a perspective that you’d imagine wouldn’t really mesh with the genre. Though I have to say it’s been done before by Orcs Must Die, and Orcs Must Die manages to achieve this gameplay from an even stranger perspective. Though, Kaiju Panic certainly has it’s unique elements and we’ll get into that in a sec.

Presentation

The game looks good. The art style certainly stands out and it was, as it usually is, the reason I requested a review copy of this game in the first place. Presentation is massively important and I feel, while it doesn’t blow me away, it certainly does the job. It’s bright, colourful, and varied between the different locations in the game. The character design I found to be pretty cute, and I while I liked the enemy design, aside from a few exceptions, the enemies were relatively generic looking. The boss-type enemies were definitely the highlight we’re talking design. They looked pretty sweet.

Mechanics

The game is standard in a few ways as you’d expect; you have a base that you need to protect from enemies that will, usually, make a beeline to the base. I say usually because about half-way through the game the enemy AI is upgraded, and they begin calculating the best places to focus their efforts which is pretty cool. I love it when games find a way to up the difficulty without turning all of the enemies into damage sponges. Really refreshing. There’s also a ton of variety, aside from the upgraded AI there’s also the lab that you can use to purchase new technology with research points -- though that’s pretty standard. You have three different types of weapons -- Cannon, Laser and Acid; they all serve different purposes, and you’ll find yourself using them all, which is nice to see. There’s also a bunch of unique mechanics; the currency you use to build weapons are these crystals. So, at the beginning of every level you must construct mining devices, and I found myself gathering people to help me while the crystal was being mined. Getting people to help you is probably the coolest mechanic of the game, where you can order civilians to man certain weapons and each civilian has their own strengths that can help add to your turrets. It’s got a really deep strategy to it and, as a tip for you if you choose to play this game, MAN THE TURRETS. I spend the first couple hours or so losing to the 5th level because I underestimated the importance of placing civilians on turrets.

Story

Story’s ok. Serves it’s purpose. Like the presentation, it’s good, but nothing to write home about. It’s there to give context to the gameplay, and that is totally fine. I don’t want to undervalue the importance of context in games, because games without any context feel slightly soulless. They feel like a tech-demo rather than a full game, and this game certainly feels like a full game. I guess what I’m saying is: it’s good the story is there, but no one is going to playing this game FOR the story. It’s super simple, like Mario saving Peach.

Verdict

Now, Kaiju Panic is $20. That seems like a lot, but hear me out. The game is long. There’s a lot of content here. Now, I’ll fully admit that I haven’t finished the entire game, but it took me around 6 hours to reach the third area, and there are six areas. Generally the levels in the third area were longer than in the second area, and the second longer than the first. I could easily see, on the high-end, this being a 15 hour game, and on the low end being a 10 hour game. That’s also backed up by the fact that new elements were being introduced in the third area, and there were tons of different weapons that I hadn’t bought yet in the lab; so the content is relatively high quality. So, is it worth $20? I’m gonna say yes if you’re going to play a lot of this game. One of the reasons I couldn’t finish it before release - and by the way I like it so I will finish it - is because I couldn’t play it in long stretches. In my opinion this game is best experiences over a long period of time where you keep coming back for more.

reviewText: I can't really recommend this game tbh. It feels like the game encourages grinding but makes grinding really really boring. I think the concept of the game is pretty cool, but the build-up in-game is slow and just isn't fun. YMMV, personally I can't recommend this game, you might enjoy it more. If it really appeals to you, buy it, play it, and refund it if you don't enjoy it. For me the game was just not fun after about an hour of play, felt like a cheap flash game at times too.
